body: As inquired by @iphydf. --- Not integrated with CMake and not actually used by c-toxcore. Someone who wants to play with CMake should integrate it. Once integrated, ~whole `toxencryptsave` dir (spare for the `.h`) can be removed. `.h` also will be possible to remove once Rust binding generator will provide 100% features set. This could be achieved right now with a work-around, but IMO there's no reason to use a work-around when there's a fully functional `.h` already. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/288)

comment_regular_data.body: Can you deduplicate the copy/pasted script? Put it in a separate script and call it.

>Can you deduplicate the copy/pasted script? Put it in a separate script and call it.

Done, although I'm not sure if it's done right.

This PR modifies Travis build scripts to build a C language bindings to @zetok's Tox implementation in Rust. I'm very confused as to what is the purpose of this. It's fine if it's just for comparative testing between two different Tox implementations, but @zetok says it's meant to replace `toxencryptsave`? Replace the

>~whole toxencryptsave dir (spare for the .h)

, which is just a 297 line `toxencryptsave.c` and 2 line `defines.h`, add zetox dependency to toxcore, and by extension Rust dependency? This sounds a bit crazy. The next thing I know we will be replacing toxcore's toxav with the toxav from the Scala implementation of Tox and toxdns with the toxdns from the Haskell implementation of Tox, while still providing the C interface for this frankenstein of a library.

@nurupo 
>This PR modifies Travis build scripts to build a C language bindings to @zetok's Tox implementation in Rust. I'm very confused as to what is the purpose of this.

Improvement. Integration & replacement. ~~Command & Conquer~~ Ahem.

Aim is to get to the point where stuff can be replaced. Which would be right about now.

The part that can be replaced is TES. Other parts (like state format {de-,}serialization) would need a bit of work, and some outline regarding how things should be done.

Rinse & repeat for $parts.

>The next thing I know we will be replacing toxcore's toxav with the toxav from the Scala implementation of Tox and toxdns with the toxdns from the Haskell implementation of Tox, while still providing the C interface for this frankenstein of a library.

And what would be the point of doing that?

Replacing C code with Rust has clear benefits. What you're describing doesn't.

I don't understand why are we merging C toxcore and Rust zetox, two separate projects, together. I would like toxcore to stay in C.

>Improvement. Integration & replacement. 

Care to elaborate more on these points?

>Aim is to get to the point where stuff can be replaced. Which would be right about now.

Why a perfectly working code should be replaced?

>Replacing C code with Rust has clear benefits. What you're describing doesn't.

Replacing C code with Scala or Haskell code has clear benefits too, but it doesn't mean that we should be doing that, at least not without any kind of discussion or a replacement plan, as it's news to me that we are planning to replace C toxcore with Rust zetox piece by piece until nothing of C toxcore is left.

>I would like toxcore to stay in C.

Why? Is there any rationale to it?

> Care to elaborate more on these points?

Not really. Internet seems to be full of explanations why using Rust and replacing C code with Rust one is the right thing to do. So all that one has to do is to google, and they'll find out why. Sorry, a bit tired trying to point out things to people who don't listen. Hopefully interested ones will google :)

Rust properties are one thing. Other, particularly in this case are code coverage, correctness, strict adherence to the spec & tests.

Seems like a clear improvement.

>Why a perfectly working code should be replaced?

Err? Where do you have this perfectly working code? Certainly not in the c-toxcore. There are plenty of bugs, lack of tests and confusing code that does almost the opposite of what one would expect from what I've heard.

Replacing horrible code helps with maintainability. Furthermore, destination language makes it way easier to write correct code for both seasoned and new to the language people, that's another clear benefit.

>Replacing C code with Scala or Haskell code has clear benefits too (…)

There are no benefits in replacing working C code with Scala or Haskell, only downsides (assuming that we're talking only in the scope of C bindings).

> (…) at least not without any kind of discussion or a replacement plan, as it's news to me that we are planning to replace C toxcore with Rust zetox piece by piece until nothing of C toxcore is left.

Well, the discussion is happening right now :-)

>Why? Is there any rationale to it?

What you are suggest doing in here is pretty much deleting C toxcore and replacing it with your own Rust zetox with C bindings. That's rather invasive. We don't have to delete C toxcore to use Rust zetox with C bindings.

>What you are suggest doing in here is pretty much deleting C toxcore and replacing it with your own Rust zetox with C bindings. That's rather invasive. We don't have to delete C toxcore to use Rust zetox with C bindings.

Yep. I've stated what can be done.

That being said, I'm curious whether there is a rationale for keeping things in C.
Please keep C core free of other things and who wants should use that Rust based Tox and let c-toxcore to be pure as it was meant to be.

Rust is probably a far better target language for a security project than c, this takes the same approach as mozilla did to integrating rust into their browser, where you replace components a bit at a time

Then best is to create Rust version of toxcore but leave c-toxcore like it is, no dependency on any part of Rust here. Tox is not browser but lightweight app for just secure communication so line cannot be tapped.

> Not really. Internet seems to be full of explanations why using Rust and replacing C code with Rust one is the right thing to do. So all that one has to do is to google, and they'll find out why. Sorry, a bit tired trying to point out things to people who don't listen. Hopefully interested ones will google :)


googled, and this is the first article i came across; http://www.viva64.com/en/b/0324/

>googled, and this is the first article i came across; http://www.viva64.com/en/b/0324/

Ah, The Blub.

Lemme help with your google-fu:

1. https://cdn.rawgit.com/Gankro/thesis/master/thesis.pdf
1. https://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html
1. https://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/17/Enums-match-mutation-and-moves.html
1. https://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/24/Rust-Once-Run-Everywhere.html
1. https://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/05/11/traits.html
1. https://medium.com/@ericdreichert/what-one-must-understand-to-be-productive-with-rust-e9e472116728
1. http://groveronline.com/2016/06/why-rust-for-low-level-linux-programming/
1. https://hacks.mozilla.org/2016/07/shipping-rust-in-firefox/
1. https://medium.com/@raphlinus/inside-the-fastest-font-renderer-in-the-world-75ae5270c445 ← leaving C/C++ behind
1. https://aturon.github.io/blog/2016/08/11/futures/ ← again, speed, `futures` lib will be used in zetox
1. http://blog.faraday.io/saved-by-the-compiler-parallelizing-a-loop-with-rust-and-rayon/
1. https://www.rust-lang.org/en-US/faq.html
1. https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/

I don't understand why this discussion is taking place at all. This is c-toxcore, a Tox implementation in C. A Tox implementation in Rust should reside in a separate repository. If people decide that the Rust version is better, they'll switch to that. There is no need to bother the c-toxcore contributors with it.
Maybe even better is to rewrite some parts in Java, C#, Python, Swift, Go, Modula-3 and so on. Little bit Fortran too.

> Lemme help with your google-fu:

i know how to search with limitation like site:rust-lang.org :/ and i do not use google either also @Impyy is right this'd not be here and as is @nurupo said, i'd like toxcore to stay in C too.
Only C in this repository :)

i don't see a big problem with mixing Rust and C code, but I see some other problems:

* Forward compatibility (as opposed to backwards compatibility): Can we ensure that we have a recent enough Rust environment on all supported platforms/distributions to compile the Rust code and it's dependencies? (I have been bitten by this...)
* Maintainers: Who besides @zetok knows Rust and is willing to fix bugs as they arise?

IMO the Rust devs created good solutions to make it compatible with C, but it won't be as easy as "rip out C file and replace by Rust file"

> Maintainers: Who besides @zetok knows Rust and is willing to fix bugs as they arise?

I'm not interested in working on a rust project.

>Can we ensure that we have a recent enough Rust environment on all supported platforms/distributions to compile the Rust code and it's dependencies?

Note: we don't need to ensure that, it'll be ensured by Firefox. I.e. as you might have noticed, one of links that I've posted is about adding Rust code in Firefox, and more of it in future.

So by extension, any platform that is capable of compiling FF or for which FF can be compiled will support Rust, simply because it's needed for FF.

Guys, maybe I'm wrong, but I believe that you should not mix different programming languages. An exception only for assembler, as it has quite a lot in common with C. But there is as you know also a lot of difficulties
@zetok let's hold off on this for now.

Right now it seems better to have two separate implementations and have equivalence testing between them. We can revisit this decision when zetox is further along, and the tests are further along as well.

commit.message:
feat: add Rust toxencryptsave

Not integrated with CMake and not actually used by c-toxcore.
Someone who wants to play with CMake should integrate it.
